awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Machine learning and video-based sensor for measuring sewer flows
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will be to provide water reclamation facilities with accurate and reliable data across all pipe flow conditions in order to make infrastructure and operational decisions. This decision-making capability is important as many facilities spend millions of dollars each year on improving sewer system function, yet are constrained by lack of quality data on sewer flows. Improved sewer flow data may help to optimize infrastructure improvements and reduce costs to taxpayers. In addition, this work may directly advance the health and welfare of the American public through improved wastewater collection systems operations and reduced overflows and basement backups. This technology has broader social implications as low-income and minority communities are disproportionately affected by flood impacts.

This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project seeks to advance a novel, non-contact sensor that collects video of wastewater flow in sanitary sewer systems to measure flow rate and detect critical sewer events. Specifically, the technology collects video of sanitary sewer flows and processes it in real time using a machine learning algorithm to measure the velocity and water level of the flow. This technology also evaluates images of sewer flows to identify illicit discharges into the system. Several key technical hurdles crucial to successful commercialization of this innovation will be addressed in the proposed project, including the use of artificial illumination systems in closed pipe environments, the development of strategies to account for rapid variations in flow rates, and the development of data analytic methods to identify critical sewer events. Given these technical hurdles, the objectives of this project will be to develop a video-based flow sensor that can accurately capture velocity and water level under expected environmental conditions and to analyze data from the proposed sensor to accurately identify critical sewer events such as blockages and illicit discharges.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The central goal of the Phase I work was to overcome key technical challenges associated with using the FluidSense sensor in sanitary sewer conditions. To that end, the main outcome of the Phase I research is the ability to accurately estimate flow velocity under various conditions using cutting-edge optical flow models combined with robust statistical methods. Through a series of laboratory experiments, we observed that our model can achieve errors lower than 10% in a variety of scenarios. We also identified a simple and effective strategy to address the limitations on the range of flow velocities that can be accurately measured by a single model. A secondary but arguably more important finding was a much deeper understanding of how optical flow models operate and how to address their limitations. We observed that the pseudo-labels we developed to evaluate our models can be used to fine-tune it, iteratively improving its performance.

The outcomes of the project have the potential for broader societal and commercial impacts through a technology that can improve collection systems operations and its subsequent impact on human and environmental health. FluidSight – a machine learning and video-based sensor for measuring sewer flows and water quality further developed in this project – can provide collection systems managers with accurate and reliable data across all pipe flow conditions that they can use to make infrastructure and operational decisions. This has a direct economic benefit, as in our customer discovery we found collection systems managers can spend upwards of hundreds of millions of dollars a year on improving sewer system function, yet are constrained by a lack of quality data on sewer flows. This lack of quality flow data results in inefficient real-time operations to reduce basement backups and overflows, and uncertain infrastructure improvements. Therefore, improved sewer flow data from our FluidSight sensor can help to optimize infrastructure improvements and reduce costs to taxpayers.

In addition, this work directly advances the health and welfare of the American public through improved collection systems operations and reduced overflows and basement backups. These unwanted overflow and basement backup events bring humans and the environment into direct contact with raw sewage, which can contaminate our waters, cause substantial property damage, and threaten public health. This has broader social implications as low-income and minority communities are disproportionately affected by flood impacts, such as basement backup. Therefore, technologies that improve our ability to manage sewer flows can have positive impacts on social and environmental justice. In addition, this type of flow sensing technology could be applied to other flow applications, such as stormwater and industrial monitoring, that are critical to environmental and human health.

 


Last Modified: 01/17/2025
Modified by: Walter Mcdonald
